A uniform board of length <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math> and mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> is attached to a pivot <math alttext="L over 4" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>L</mi><mn>4</mn></mfrac></math> from the left end of the board. The left end of the board is attached to an ideal spring of spring constant <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math> that is attached to the ground. The right end of the board is initially held by a student so that the spring is unstretched, as shown in Figure <math alttext="1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. The student slowly lowers and then releases the board. The board remains at rest in the horizontal position, with the spring stretched, as shown in Figure <math alttext="2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>. The rotational inertia of the board about the pivot is <math alttext="I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math>. (a) On the rectangle below, which represents the board, draw and label the forces (not components) that act on the board while the board-spring system is in equilibrium. Each force should be represented by an arrow that starts on, and points away from, the board, and should represent the location at which that force acts.

(b) Derive an expression for the distance the spring stretches, <math alttext="delta x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>∆</mo><mspace width="-0.2em"></mspace><mi>x</mi></math>, when the board is in equilibrium. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math>, <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math>, <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

(c) A student pushes the board down on the right side, stretching the spring a new distance <math alttext="delta x sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>∆</mo><mspace width="-0.2em"></mspace><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> from the unstretched position. The board is held at a small angle <math alttext="theta sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> with the horizontal, as shown. The student then releases the board from rest.

i. At time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, the board is released. At <math alttext="t equals t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, the board first crosses the horizontal. Sketch a graph of the magnitude of the angular acceleration <math alttext="alpha" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>α</mi></math> of the board as a function of time <math alttext="t" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi></math> from <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> to <math alttext="t equals t sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>.

ii. Derive an expression for the angular acceleration <math alttext="alpha sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> of the board immediately after the board is released. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="k" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>k</mi></math>, <math alttext="L" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>L</mi></math>, <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math>, <math alttext="I" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>I</mi></math>, <math alttext="delta x sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>∆</mo><mspace width="-0.2em"></mspace><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="theta sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>θ</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate.

(d) Two blocks of equal mass <math alttext="m" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>m</mi></math> are attached to the board equal distances from the pivot point, as shown. The board is again pushed down on the right side so that the spring stretches the same distance <math alttext="delta x sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mo>∆</mo><mspace width="-0.2em"></mspace><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math> as in part (c). The board is then released. How does the new angular acceleration <math alttext="alpha prime" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>α</mi><mo>'</mo></math> when the blocks are attached compare to the angular acceleration <math alttext="alpha sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> from part (c) ? ___ <math alttext="alpha prime is greater than alpha sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>α</mi><mo>'</mo><mo>></mo><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> ___ <math alttext="alpha prime is less than alpha sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>α</mi><mo>'</mo><mo><</mo><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> ___ <math alttext="alpha prime equals alpha sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>α</mi><mo>'</mo><mo>=</mo><msub><mi>α</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>Justify your answer.
